resources.string: PID Tuner is a comprehensive app designed to help engineers and control systems professionals fine-tune PID controllers using various established tuning methods.\nThe app provides intuitive tools for selecting and applying different tuning algorithms based on system characteristics and desired performance.
PID Tuner help icon. Goes to PID Tuner help page.
PID Tuner is an application developed to help engineering students to compute controller parameters based on most common methods available, it is only for study purposes.
Select the tuning method to obtain the proportional, integral and derivative parameters

The Cohen-Coon method is a popular PID tuning technique mainly for first-order systems with time delay. It aims to improve disturbance rejection and has better performance for processes with dead time.
The IAE method minimizes the absolute error over time. It prioritizes the total error accumulation, leading to smoother control but potentially slower response times.

IMC is based on the principle that the controller contains an explicit model of the process. It provides a systematic way of tuning controllers with the ability to handle model uncertainties and process delays.
Choose the Process Model with the controller
ITAE minimizes the integral of time-weighted absolute error, focusing on reducing error over longer periods. It generally results in less oscillatory responses compared to other methods.
This method is similar to Ziegler-Nichols but is better suited for tuning PI and PID controllers in slower, more oscillatory systems. It provides more stable control with less aggressive behavior.
One of the earliest tuning methods, Ziegler-Nichols uses experimental testing to set PID parameters. It aims for an aggressive, fast response but often results in overshoot and oscillations.

Welcome to PID Tuner
PID Tuner gathers several PID controller tuning methods.
Z&N, CHR, CC, IMC, IAE and ITAE methods are available to calculate the controller parameters 
(Proportional, Integral and Derivative) using the process parameters 
(Gain, Time Constant and Dead Time).

Ziegler and Nichols proposed two approach, the first approach is based on open-loop system, and the second is based on closed-loop system.

The Open-loop (plant) refers to methods to tune controller when it is in manual state, it is based on step response.

The Closed-loop (plant) refers to methods to tune controller when it is in automatic state.\nIt is based on sustained oscillations response.\nThe figure below shows the step response when Gain is raised until Ultimate Gain, causing sustained oscillations; the graph helps to obtain the Ultimate Period (Pu).

In PID Tuner, Ziegler and Nichols Method for Opened-Loop requires only Process Gain, Time Constant and Process Transport Delay (Dead Time) and Closed-Loop requires the Ultimate Gain (Ku) and Ultimate Period (Pu).

PS: The method Tyreus-Luyben is closed-loop tuning, so it requires Ultimate Gain (Ku) and Ultimate Period (Pu).

Lambda Tuning is a form of Internal Model Control (IMC).
Its name is from Greek letter called lambda (λ) and it is a parameter required to compute the controller parameters, besides, of course, Process Gain, Time Constant and Transport Delay.

The lambda is an user-specified performance/robustness parameter that specifies how fast or how long the controller must spend to process the system response (Y) to reach the setpoint.
The IMC Method in PID Tuner is based on technique proposed by Morari and Zafiriou in \'Robust Process Control\' of PID tunings for first order plus dead time function.

This method focuses on optimizing the controller for either setpoint tracking or disturbance rejection. It provides specific tuning formulas based on the desired system response, like minimal overshoot or fast response.
